answers.body: Just the usual vomiting and diarrhea. No hospital visits. We all had it at the same time during one night while on safari and staying in a small cabin so likely spoiled food from a roadside stop on the way there. That was a night to remember for sure with only one bathroom between four of us. Several doses of strong antibiotics, water with electrolytes and soda water and 24 hours later all was fine and forgotten.We loved India as my wife has family there. Travelled the southern third and then the golden triangle. India is great for travel with hiring drivers and cars for ten days at a time and with kids it was much cheaper than private safari in Africa. And with the lions and other animals, they will not be off in the distance, they will be right beside the vehicle.

title: 3 Days in Nairobi before Safari - what to do

answers.body: We went on a safari last year. Before the safari we enjoyed 2 days in Nairobi. We hired a driver who picked us up from our hotel (The Sarova Stanley). We went to the Elephant orphanage, Kazuri Bead factory (hand made bead--made by local widows from the area--go and support them if you can--nice jewlery that you can only get in Nairobi) and to the Giraffe Center. We also asked our driver to take us to a shopping center so we could buy some snacks and drinks. He also took us by the slums of Nairobi (Kibera). I wish we would have spent more time in the slums. The people there were so friendly and the living conditions were so much different than what we see in America.We also changed money at a bank at the "mall." This bank had a much better exchange rate than we got at the hotel. Also, it is better to haveKenyashillings for the Elephant orphanage and the Giraffe center. No credit cards accepted and the rate for US money (which they do accept) is far, far worse than if you use their currency.we went to Karen Blixen's Coffee House for lunch too--such a nice place to eat!!! You will love it!Hope this helps!!

body: I am flying into Nairobi on a Saturday evening in August (flight is scheduled to arrive at 6:10pm) in advance of a Kilimanjaro trek the following week - starting from Moshi.Any suggestions on transport?I did look in my Tanzania Lonely Planet book, but am having a lot of trouble sorting through the various options:I think there might be at least one overnight (Scandinavian?) bus leaving late Saturday night. On the other hand, I am considering spending that Saturday night in a Nairobi hotel and then catching a bus on Sunday.Any thoughts/suggestions/recommendations would be greatly appreciated... both about the bus or perhaps about a convenient hotel to stay at for the night in Nairobi if I choose to do that.Thanks!Sam
title: Nairobi to Moshi transport questions

answers.body: I highly discourage overnight buses in East Africa period. It's the height of banditry and when most fatal accidents occur (though this is rare on that route). If you have never been in Africa before (especiallyKenya), it would be nice for you to travel during the day so you have your bearings. People unfamiliar with their surroundings (it seems) are more commonly victims of crime/petty theft. Not to scare you, but I've heard so many stories (and never been a crime victim myself because I'm overly-cautious) so I think you should heed my advise. You would be best-served to take a bus or shuttle the next morning and grab a hotel on Sunday. You will route through Arusha and then onward to Moshi. The Impala shuttle is comfortablehttp://www.impalashuttle.com/and will get you to Moshi. Riverside shuttle is another option, but there have been a few bad reviews on this forum latelyhttp://www.riverside-shuttle.com/.I can't speak for Scandinavian, as the quality of buses change from year to year or month to month. It used to look decent (haven't ever taken them myself) but that can change quickly. I like the shuttles, and they are pretty comfortable compared to the buses. Again a bus in Kenya cannot be compared to a bus in the US.Good luck.
answers.title: 1.Re: Nairobi to Moshi transport questions

answers.body: Best to spend first night in Nairobi, get a good night's rest before considering going onward. Especially not a good idea to do this in the dark.Spend the night in Nairobi and if time allows for when you begin your trek from Moshi, do some sightseeing in/around and maybe head out the followiing day - Monday.However many days in NBO, please no nighttime bus rides. Whether Impala, Riverside or Scandinavia, best to ride during daylight hours.

Then back to the Fairview, so traffic shouldn't be all that much of a factor. And, if the day you are planning this is a Sunday, very little traffic in the morning, though more later in the day.There's also a nice cafe at Utamaduni Crafts (near Kazuri Beads) at more reasonable prices than Karen Blixen Coffee/Tamambo,(but then lots of cuisine choices in NBO, so whatever you might wish). title: Stop-over: Wishing to visit Nairobi National Park

answers.body: For your 4pm departure you have to be back at the airport by 2pm.Keeping that in mind, most sites don't open before 9am... Nairobi Natl Prk,Karen Blixen Museum, Giraffe Center, 11am visit Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage (finished by 12N), time for quick lunch. Each site has a small entry free from a few hundredKenyashillings to, I believe, $40 for theNational Park.Leaving the airport during rush hour it can take you a short 45/min (unlikely) or long 2/hrs to get to your first stop for opening, i.e., Nairobi NP.Deplaning, you have to purchase a Transit Visa $20, suggest you withdraw from ATM some local currency to cover your fees, then go out and find a taxi (negotiate the fare for 4/hrs) for driver to take you to these sites, wait for you and return you to airport by 2pm.I'm sure others will have additional input. Hope this helps

title: 8 hours in Nairobi, please help for the schedule

answers.body: Depends on what your interests are. If you're an Out of Africa fan, you can't miss the Blixen Museum. If you're not an Out of Africa fan, you might not find it so interesting. The museum is very close to theGiraffe Centreand Sheldrick. Don't know if you're interested in any shopping stops but also nearby are Kazuri Beads & Pottery and Utamaduni which has a craft collection (prices a bit high but good quality and selection). If you decide to go to the Blixen Museum in the afternoon, I'd stick with the Carnivore for lunch asHaandiis in Westlands and you don't want to have to drive back and forth across the city. Or pick some place in the Karen/Langata area to have lunch.The Verandahrestaurant at Utamaduni is a nice spot. But of course, not the same atmosphere as Carnivore.I haven't been to theNational Museum. Tried to visit several times but it was always under renovation. Lunch at Haandi would be fine if that's your afternoon plan.Another museum is theRailway Museumby the train station. It houses old engines, rail cars and memorabilia from the East African Railway if that's something that might interest you.Enjoy your trip!

answers.title: 1.Re: Place near Nairobi?

answers.body: In answer to your questions1. Attractions are spread out across Nairobi. For example, places like theGiraffe Centre,Karen Blixen Museum, Elephant Orphanage, Animal Orphanage andNational Parkare all very close to Karen, on the outskirts. If you were to stay somewhere like, say,Macushla House, you would be located in Langata and therefore within 15-20 minutes' driving time of all of the above, traffic permitting. Then, for the downtown attractions such as theNational Museumand others listed in the previous post, you could organise with your hotel / B&B to hire a taxi plus driver for the day to take you into town and wait while you visit them. Alternatively, you could stay in a downtown hotel and do your sightseeing vice versa. Personally speaking, I'd go for the outskirts option as it's cheaper and quieter and Nairobi, IMHO, is a pretty grotty city!2. For accommodation on the outskirts I would recommend:Macushla HouseNgong HouseGiraffe ManorPalacina Suites/ResidenceHTHFL410

answers.body: Assume this is for 2014? What month? How many days in-country?Peak season prices are from July thru October.Know that theGiraffe Manoralready for '14 has limited space and the rate on a full-board basis -BLD- is in the range of $500/pp/nt... checkin 11am, checkout 10am... no hanging around outside these hours unless you are a paying guest.Best you pick-up a guidebook with further details of what's available (game at specific areas), whether you wish to drive or fly between areas. Lots of other useful information.And only way you'll know what your final costs will be... contact a few outfitters (select from the KATO site - www.katokenya.org), sending individual emails to about 6, with your wish list including estimated budget.Bye the way, Nairobi Nat'l Park while interesting is nowhere like a visit to the Masai Mara and/or other parks/reserves. And know that you can see game as close if only sitting in front of your room or tent; you don't always have to go on game drives.During stay in Nairobi, unless selecting a hotel in a questionnable area to beging with, you're safe in most all tourist hotels - much as hotels elsewhere around the world.

answers.title: 3.Re: 1 week to explore area

answers.body: I may be a bit biased, but I feel just remaining in Nairobi doesn't give the best picture ofKenyaas a whole. It is a land of amazing contrasts - from the Coast to the cooler heights. From lush farmland to desert. From well dressed, seemingly rich, people to the desperately poor and needy.You can cross the Equator at over 9000ft and feel cold up there!! You can swim in pools fed by hot springs.........I am a "people person" - most Kenyans are warm hearted and friendly. In your charity work, you are very likely to see needs which may make you a bit uncomfortable doing some touristy things!! If I were you, I'd not make too many plans in advance, unless you want to book a safari. (In that case you can get much advice on this forum.)TIA (This Is Africa) and last minute decisions are the norm, unless it it booking a popular hotel or safari!

answers.body: Hi Mike,I have just returning fromKenyaon a volunteer program based inKibera. Yes i would recommend a trip through Kibera. The only reason i suggest this is because you mentioned your work inUganda. Kibera is not for the average 'tourist'.Things are quite bad there and the mere size of the place is unbelievable. 1.5 million people living in a 'real' slum. It is the largest in all of africa. There is a spot at a school called 'olympic' where you can get a great view of Kibera.Despite the conditions the people, especially the kids, are great.If you can find someone a local that is trustworthy get them to take you through. If you can get them to drive you to an area Jamhuri and then it is a 10min walk to Kibera. If you stay on the outer rim and don't take valuable you will get a better feel than a drive through. Just don't go at night. During the day you shouldn't have any probelms as long as you use common sense. I used to walk to the orphange by myself.Gypsygirl8

answers.body: You can go birding almost anywhere in Nairobi. Karen is a pretty large area, with lots of long, tree-lined roads and lanes, so not realistic to walk around and cover completely. But any large garden or quiet road will have dozens of species. The longstanding regular bird walks in Nairobi are conducted by Fleur Ngweno (immortalised in Nicholas Drayson's novel "A Guide to the Birds of East Africa") which set off from theNational Museumevery Wed morninghttp://naturekenya.org/Happy birding!Richard Trillo

body: HiI will have 2 days in Nairobi mid November, November 14-15 in the weekend before business trip - would like to see wildlife, light hiking ok and no need to do it complete luxury style, but should be safe, hygienic etc - what is recommended to do? I arrive Friday night at 9 pm in Nairobi with KLM.I do not have any budget restrictions as such.Best regardsChristian Wieth
title: Weekend in Nairobi

answers.body: If no budget restrictions, you can consider- first thing Sat morning, transfer to Wilson (domestic) airport for 10am flight to Masai Mara, have game drive, overnight; Sunday morning game drive and afternoon game drive to airstrip for 4pm flight to Wilson.-Instead of the Masai Mara, you could fly 7:30am to Amboseli or (9-something) to Samburu, both known for large elephant herds; Amboseli also has views of Kili; Samburu has species not found elsewhere as: reticulated giraffe, Grevy's zebra, gerenuk, Somali ostrich, Beisa oryx and even wild dogs.However, with these two destinations, there are only morning flights so once back in NBO on Sun, you'd have half-day free, but there is some interesting sightseeing:Karen Blixen Museum, Giraffe Center, by 11am Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage; if you adopt an ellee (see the Sheldrick site) you can arrange to visit your chubby at 5pm to meet the keeper and put your ward to sleep... lots of fun .---You'd incur fee for return flights, 1/nt lodge or camp (many choices at different budgets), meals, park fees, game drives and transfers - your hotel can arrange, but I'd prebook before arrival.Easier and probably less expensive probably- Sat morning, road trip to Lake Nakuru; game drive, hotel overnight Lion Hill Lodge; next morning (Sun) early game drive and drive south (1/hr) to Naivasha for boat ride to Crescent Island for walking safari amongst tame game; return to NBO by evening. (about 2-2.5/hrs drive time)OR- Sat morning, road trip to Ol Pejeta, private conservation - stay at Sweetwater's, Porini Camp or Ol Pejeta Bush Camp (if open in Nov); game drives, night game drives; Sunday, game or walking safaris; return to NBO by evening. (about 2-2.5/hrs drive time).--- Cost for either of these should include: guide/vehicle, park fees, room/tent, meals, game drives and all transfersHope this helps.

body: It looks like we have about a 6 hour layover before coming back home in the Nairobi airport around 5pm. Was thinking about possible going into Nairobi for dinner from the airport. Is this advisable, and if so how is best to do it safely? Thank you.
title: Layover

answers.body: I do this quite often. Land at 4pm from Kigali and then fly out on the 11pm to London. BUT a few provisos: I always check my bags through and I always have my boarding card for the second leg of my flight (online check in is fab), so all I have to do on my return to the airport is go through immigration. I also tend to fly on a Sunday night, when the roads are quiet(er), so I can be in and out of town quickly.You will need to buy a transit visa for $10. If you're not at the front of the queue I wouldn't bother as you'll waste too much time and you might just as well sit at Java Coffee by gate 14.I tend to go to Karen rather than town (nicer restaurants) -Talisman,Rusty Nailetc - just jump in a cab at the airport, and get the restaurant to book one for your return. It'll cost you c1200Ksh into town (30 mins) and c1500Ksh to Karen (40mins). I tend to head back so I'm at the airport 90 mins before the flight.This has gone spectacularly wrong on one occassion when the traffic was so bad it took 4 hours to get back from Karen.If you wanted something closer you could go to dinner at the Parnasi (sp?) Hotel which is about 10 minutess from the airport.If in any doubt on time don't do it.

answers.body: Just be warned about the Nairobi traffic - 5pm could be dreadful!!Our visitors last week took 2 1/2 hours to get into Nairobi at noon and missed their planned trip to the Game Park.Personally I'd not bother!! The Cafe up past Gate 14 looks nice....

title: One night in Nairobi

answers.body: The closest hotels to the airport would be Panari orOle Sereni... about 10-15/min taxi drive, however they're not inexpensive. Going any farther into the city may find yourself in situation next morning with horrific traffic for return to the airport.If leaving the airport to overnight at hotel, you will have to purchase a Visa at USD$50/person and might need for entry toZimbabwea Yellow Fever inoculation and proof of same or you won't be allowed in. I'd check with Zim Embassy if this inoc is needed which is rather expensive. Also, taxi to/from hotel.And, for a 7:20am flight you have to be at airport for check-in/security at minimum 2/hrs prior departure (it's an international flight). Thus, gather you'd have to be up, showered, dressed, had breakfast and out of hotel by 5am.While NBO airport isn't attractive enough nor at all comfortable, services limited... you might do better finding a quiet spot here to catch some Zzzzs. Some shops will be open and though few places to eat, Java (Coffee) House is best you might be able to "hang" here till early morning.Good luck!

answers.body: You don't say whether you are transiting or staying longer? There isn't an airport shuttle bus - some of the better hotels might offer their own transport which you would have to arrange beforehand. The best thing is to order a private cab to wait for you - the driver will meet you at the barriers just outside the customs check at arrivals.As the OPs have mentioned, traffic at that time of the night is negligible, however if you need to return to the airport the next day to catch a flight allow at least 2 hours to get there, especially in the late afternoon or on Fridays. Even if the normal traffic is okay, quite often something happens (like a police shoot out with gangsters, or the presidential calvalcade, or a political speech at the stadium - all of which have happened to me) which stops traffic for hours on end (which means the cab might have trouble even getting to pick you up, let alone deliver you to the airport).If you are staying for a while, choose a hotel near the city or at Westlands - Westlands is safer I reckon, and there are cafes and restaurants there and at the Sarit Centre so you aren't stuck at the hotel, plus shops and the Maasai markets (in tin sheds on the corner opposite Sarit Centre) to buy some gifts. (The touts at the markets can be quite pushy though, so maybe team up with someone else if possible.)Jacaranda Hotelis fine and doesn't charge like a wounded bull.Also check TripAdvisor for guesthouses etc - the Mennonite Guesthouse off Rhapta Road is about 40 mins walk from Westlands shops, for example, but don't walk at night or evening.Andrews Apartments(also a hotel - at the end of Rhapta Road near St Marys schools) is really nice with a quiet green outlook (ask for a room looking over St Marys parkland) and pool, but not sure of their pricing.Also, maybe make a deal with your cab driver to drive you around for your stay - public transport as we know it doesn't exist, and can be dangerous. I can recommend Francis from Westline Travel (+254 (0) 724 988 866), or Nellion cabs (+254 (0) 734 354 738), or JimCabs. One way trip from JKIA into town/Westlands will be 1500 shillings - this is the standard. Further out (say to Karen) would be more.

body: I'm sure there's someone out there who can advise me!I'm staying at theFairview Hotelfor 2 nights in Nairobi before joining a project and would like to do the tourist bit - elephant orphanage etc. for one day. answers.body: Hi skipuss,Using a taxi would be a cheaper option for you but you might need a guide. This is a safe way to travel around Nairobi. Finding an organized group might not be easy because of conflict of dates and timings.Apart from the elephant orphanage you can do the giraffe manor> nice place to interact within the giraffes one on one. The safari walk and animalorphanage also are nice places to visit. All this can be done in one day but the elephant orphanage only opens for one hour. Btw 11 and 12 to minimize their tolerance to human beings.All the best.

answers.body: Or you could adopt a baby ele and then you can arrange to go for longer in the day.
answers.title: 3.Re: Best way to be a single tourist for 1 day in Nairobi

answers.body: A day in Nairobi can be such fun!! Of course, the elephants are a must. Are you a foster parent of one of the orphans? If you are, did you know you can have a more private viewing in the evening when you can meet your baby personally!!! This was definitely a highlight for me. Email the trust to arrange. Other highlights are theGiraffe Centrewhere you can feed the giraffes and learn more about them,Karen Blixen Museum(Out of Africa), Bomas of Africa, a cultural village where you will learn about the tribes and watch them perform,Utamaduni Craft Centrefor more up-market crafts. Carnivore Restaurant is also a lot of fun but probably better if you have company. All of these attractions are in Langata an outer suburb of Nairobi, so all close by to each other.I have friends in the safari business in Nairobi who I would recommend to you, but not sure how their cost would compare to other forms of travel for a single person. Please try them.East Africa Discoveries and Safaris, run by Isaac Kariuki, email safari@eastafricad.co.ke OR eastafricad@yahoo.com.www.eastafricad.co.keAsk for David to guide you ... he is also a friend and a wonderful guide, very professional and polite. I am also a middle aged female and always felt safe in his company. I loveKenyawith a passion and will definitely be going back. I'd love to know more about your project ... please reply??!!!

They're allowed to transfer guests after the park has closed, and transfers and full-on game drives in the park are included in the price. Because it's located on the south side of the national park, you can get from the lodge to anywhere in Karen by popping out through Langata gate and straight to JKIA/Wilson by using East Gate. answers.body: Planning trip to Nairbo,Kenyaend of November. Coming from USA. Is it more economical to pay for food, services, shopping, etc with US dollars or use a VISA card instead exchanging US dollars for shillings?
answers.title: 8.Re: Currency, things to do in five days

answers.body: Food, services (except for hotels/safari) and shopping are priced in Kenya Shillings. Although US Dollars are likely to be accepted, you are unlikely to be offered a favourable exchange rate. It is better to bring some cash which you can exchange, or withdraw Kenya Shillings from ATM's (ensuring that you notify your bank of travel plans). Card payments are accepted in many retail outlets, but more remotely located outlets eg. curio shops will operate on a cash basis.Also, I would urge you to pay tips in Kenya Shillings. Kenyan's are too polite to turn down a tip made in US Dollars. However, the reality is that the member of staff might not be readily able to change the money and will also lose on the exchange, as well as possibly needing to pay for travel to a bank/forex. I also believe that it demonstrates respect and forethought to pay tips in the legal tender.

It was replaced later by theSafari Baron the first floor and later still by theExchange Bar. This last was the birthplace of Nairobi's first and only Stock Exchange where previously four businessmen had sat, since 1954, transacting their business of stocks and shares.

answers.title: 1.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

answers.title: 2.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

answers.body: Not sure if you are doing 1 or 2 visits to the elephant orphanage. Public is 111am-12n and a short talk about the ellies and watching them have their mudbaths. Make sure you either wear something that you don't care about because they can splash the mud on you but fun to watch. The evening visit from 5-6pm, for those that have adopted ellies, is a different experience and very enjoyable. You get to meet the keepers and see your adopted chubby.Kazuri beads is also great. The tour of the bead making area is very interesting and the ladies very proud of their work. Their finished products are very reasonable in cost here. If you buy the same type of items at lodging, they are way more expensive.Utmanduni Crafts is also in the Karen area and is a great place to have lunch and shop. There is no pressure on the shopping like other places you might encounter. You can browse and bring your items to a central checkout. Prices are slightly higher than booths along the road, but it is wonderful to not have to haggle. They have clean bathrooms and their food is good and very reasonable.Laurena
answers.title: 3.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

answers.body: First Free day:A Nairobi Walking Tourwhich includes a walking Safari in Nairobi Central Business District. have a wonderful walk of the city-in-the-sun with a local guide where you have ample time for close photography, bargain and diversified shopping.Visiting the stately Parliament buildings, Kenyatta International Conference Centre and the colorful Nairobi city market lift to the top of KICC to look at Nairobi skyline can be arranged) also are Visits to Kenya National archives & Watatu art gallery.Thereafter, a visit to theSnake ParkandNational Museum: "the Finest Small Museum in Africa" well known for its spell binding exhibits and displays of early man, tribal regalia and the flora and fauna ofKenyaalso a close visit to the botanical garden.Second Free day, I would suggest as it is the last day a Nairobi Cultural Experience Tour with Shopping.If you may have any questions please don't hesitate to contact me.All the best !
answers.title: 4.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

Afternoon doKIBERAslum as you go back to Hotel.On 15th Sep, depart Hotel for the OSTRICH FARM at Kitengela 30kms from Nairobi city same route to Airport, spend the whole morning there and after Lunch drive about 15kms from OSTRICH FARM to Airport for your flight, it is will be so nice and good experience.All the best.Ancient Wild.

answers.body: A note on the Nairobi walking tour suggestion:The parliament area is now under hair-trigger security due to terror threats. I would not be walking where you see any obvious security perimeter. I'm not sure where the current perimeter is, but don't stray too near large concentrations of police, and I would not have a camera in my hand either.Anywhere in the Central Business District (CBD), you could attract negative attention these days if you try to capture street views with a camera. A sad state of affairs I realize, but recently a white British terrorist was killed inKenyaand this really got the public's attention.

body: Does anyone have suggestions for a reliable, well priced car-hire company in Nairobi for a short-term rental? A small 4wd (eg Suzuki Jimney) or bakkie or elevated vehicle would be ideal, but small sedan also ok.And any tips on driving, ability to find parking.Thanks
title: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: I always recommend Corcorde - I've used them many times and found their Suzukis (well, Marutis) very reliable, and they're well located in the heart of Westlands, just off Waiyaki Way.Driving tips? Where to begin?! You need to be robustly defensive, always alert, and always prepared for the worst possible outcome. It's much better to hire a driver when you hire the vehicle. Parking is a serious problem in the CBD and other busy areas. Buy parking tickets (usually valid all day) from parking wardens. And beware the city askaris, who are a law unto themselves…Happy driving!Richard Trillo

answers.body: Yacht,I supposeBangkokis a fair comparison.If you are only going between Jomo and Karen, with a few trips for birds and NBO Park, I cannot see you encountering any major problems. The Park is off Langata Rd, which is what you will use to get to Keran from Jomo. At the moment there are some works going on there, so it is a little more depressing than usual, but no world shattering.Also, the Park is one of those on the ‘Card system’, you could actually stop and do all the paperwork the day before going in, thus making entry quicker on the morning you visit. Sometimes there can be a queue at the desk, and anything you can do to avoid it gives you more time actually in there! Ideally, you want to hit the Gate at 0630ish.I would also opt for Ngong over Karuru forest, nothing to do with the birds, I don’t know enough, just that the latter is over by Muthaiga and you’d have to battle through town!If you come out early, and are puckish, there is a reasonable place to eat just by the Gift Shop, then you can get back on the road to theGiraffe Centre, that has a small Café too, but is really form emergency eats! You may also wish to consider the Elephant Orphange, also in the area, time dependant.For a good feed in the evening, I would head for theTalisman, excellent place about 2 mins from Karen Shops, get your hotel to book a table though, it can get a little busy and try to eat on the Patio, it makes for a nice evening.Do beware, particularly when heading into the road-works on Langata of Matatus, they don’t take prisoners and will when the traffic merges attempt to push you off the road to make space for themselves. For a first time driver over there, I would say bow out gracefully and let them in, it is better than ending up in the ditch.Be lucky and enjoy!

answers.body: Couple of thoughts:Arriving at JKIA mid-afternoon Friday and trying to drive to Karen, you will probably (depending on flight arrival time) get as far as Uhuru Stadium roundabout before encountering traffic heading left (west) to Karen that will take you 1-2 hours, so don't expect to be in Karen much before dark (6.30pm).I'd suggest you might do better to get a taxis on Friday and Sunday and have a car and driver for the whole of Saturday, someone who will pick you up from where you're staying and drop you back at the end of the day. title: Stuff to do in Nairobi

answers.body: We had a request like that some time back and ended up doing the below itinerary which catered for our day. The trip was made possible by diwaka safaris based in Nairobi and we were provided with an extra free guide..if need be,just write to joseph@diwakasafaris.com11thPicked at 1000hrs for a 20 mins drive to the Daphne Sheldrik Elephant orphanage for a one hour learning experience about the playful young elephants and rhino that were rescued. (1100-1200hrs).The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trustis a small flexible charity, established in memory of David Sheldrick, famous Naturalist and founder Warden of Kenya's giant Tsavo East National Park in which he served from 1948 until 1976.The trust has been active in an educative capacity and provided a blue print for the welfare of animals in captivity and in cases of elephants, illustrated the sophistication of their communication and their social needs.1230hrs: Taken to a restaurant where you pay for your lunch directly1400hrs: Proceed short drive to the nearbyGiraffe Centre.It’s a sanctuary for the rare and beautiful Rothschild Giraffe set by Jock a British-born Kenyan citizen with the help of her American Wife Betty Leslie-Melville. Not only will you get to have a close view of the tall mammals but also be able to have a rare chance to hold a wild animal as you feed them ending with a most wonderful kiss from them. The residents’ warthogs are also a good sight to catch with their “same as” pig behavior.1500hrs: End the day with a visit to theKaren Blixen Museumplus shopping before been dropped back at the Hilton Hotel.A visit to the original home of the famous Danish Authoress of (Out of Africa Movie fame) giving you an incredible chance to learn more about the widely respected woman as you take a graceful walk around the around her spacious bungalow. You can take a walk around the beautiful gardens with spectacular view of the knuckles likeNgong Hillswhere Blixen boyfriend Denys Finch Hatton was remains were laid to rest on May 14 1931.

answers.title: 2.Re: Best use of One Day at Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Hello,I work withGiraffe Manoras their sales and marketing representative in Europe and hope I can help here. The giraffe visit the Manor in the morning until around 8am. It is difficult to say exactly where they will be and when as they have the whole garden to explore throughout the day, but it is safe to say that you will see them before 8am up at the Manor and also around tea time when they like to come up again! I have arrived at the manor at various times of the day and there is almost always a giraffe in sight , be it by the Manor or just down the hill.Re: what to do, you can walk to the giraffe centre from the Manor so, as you say this is a must. I would suggest going to the private session only at the Daphne Sheldrick orphanage. This is far more personalised and you will be able to ask specific questions about your elephant as well as seeing some of the others. The afternoon session can have as many as 150 people there and, although interesting for those who are not able to have a private viewing, is not as special. I would suggest that, as your time is short that you only do the private session.Depending on what you are most interested in, whilst you are coming back from the Daphne Sheldrick orphanage I would highly recommend stopping in at Marula studios. This is where they recycle flipflops from the Kenyan coast (they are washed up onto the beach and turtles have been killed by trying to eat them so they are removed and brought to Nairobi). Here they are made into all sorts of wonderful things such as toys, jewellery, mats etc. You can look around the factory and then head into the shop to see the end products. Kazuri beads is great for souvenir shopping and Matt Bronze is great to visit / see the bronzes being made and buy something of quality. Karen Blixen is also nice to see if you are interested in her history, but again, depending on your time you may want to get back to the Manor. You really do not want to miss out on the tea on the lawn with giraffe! Once you are back at the Manor you can enjoy the rest of the day / evening there. What is great is that the Manor is close to all these places, so it really comes down to your own preference. Hope this helps and you have a wonderful time there!

answers.body: Here's my 2 shillings worth:Giraffe Manoris a unique place to stay. It's 28km from Nairobi International Airport and assuming you're out of the airport and moving in a vehicle by 7.30am (pretty good going if you are), you won't be at Giraffe Manor until 9 or 9.30am, except possibly on a Sunday. BUT, you won't be able to check-in until 10.45/11am for the reasons Sandi states - there's no waiting area, no lobby and they're checking guests *out* between 10 and 11. So, you'll be hanging around for a bit, possibly at the AFEW Giraffe Centre itself (to which as guests of GM you would have free access, though possibly only once you've checked in…), which is just across the lawn, on the edge of the manor grounds.The bigger question is: if you aren't already holding a room at Giraffe Manor, book one soon. It's often full.As for the question of how to fill the 24 hours: "Karen Blixen museum, bomas, Matt Bronze, Kazuki beads, open air market - which one?" Kazuri Beads is nice, but I wouldn't pass up the opportunity to visitNairobi National Parkproperly - it's a really impressive 60 square miles of wilderness, not some sanitised city park, and you have a very good chance of seeing lions, and even greater chance (amazingly) of seeing both black and white rhinos.Have a great stay in Nairobi - a greatly underrated city.Richard Trillo

body: I got roped into a holiday with the family toKenyaand am a bit nervous as my 2.5 year old toddler with be accompanying us too! Any comments on how child-friendly a place Nairobi is? My main queries surround entertainment (parks/playgrounds), health and safety (food/water) and infrastructure (cleanliness, public toilets, change-facilities, etc). Its too late to change plans now, so the best I can do is make sure that my kid is healthy, relatively well entertained and happy! We're going on a couple of private safaris where kids are allowed, though I wonder if he'll really enjoy them. Any warnings, pointers, hints, suggestions, advice is welcome!
title: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: I'm not sure I would have taken such a young child. I think 5 is possibly the earliest I would take a little one. At the very least they need to be able to take malaria prophylactics and I don't think I could have got the tablets into my kids at that age.Having said that just make sure that he/she has all the recommended jabs; use bottled water; take care with the sun - all the things that apply to anyone really - and you should be OK.There are things for little ones in Nairobi - the elephant orphanage and giraffe centre are perfect. There is also Uhuru park which has pedallos, rides etc. Most hotels have swimming pools too so you should be able to fill the time that you are there and most Kenyans do like children - well at least that's been my experience.
answers.title: 1.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: We took our two young ones last year ages 4 and 8 (younger one turned 5 while in the Mara - "best birthday present ever") We had private driver so that we could change plans, stop whenever needed, etc. Children will love it, but maybe not remember it as much as an older child would.We were able to get medicine in them by crushing and mixing with chocolate pudding so it can be done. Bottle water all the way, hats, sunscreen and short days and you will be fine. If you have not already, be sure to visit travel clinic and get antibiotic prescriptions filled ahead for all travellers and take with you for emergency. We were there for 35 days and used ours.Don't expect to be taking a stroller as it will be useless on the poor roads, sidewalks except maybe in downtown Nairobi. Back pack carrier for that age might be useful. But taxis and guide will get you wherever you need to go so you should not have to carry that much.And to compare, we also went to India for 60 days when youngest was at the around same age as yours.Kenyais much cleaner and safer than crowed India.
answers.title: 2.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: Be sure to prearrange for a bed (even a crib) with a bed net for the little one. Not all camps/lodges have these as they're not always necessary, but I sure would for a little one. And for certain be sure to give him/her their malaria meds daily. There are a few types, but Malarone does have a pediatric dosage for child under 40lbs. Discuss with doc meds and inocs that all might need as even most adults haven't been since childhood - Tetanus, HepA, Polio.Besides forgetting about a stroller, know that most safari vehicles have seat belts but NOT childseats, so you might want to seriously consider one as the roads in some areas aren't the best. The little one will also often need a nap midday, so having one is best.Also be aware that you can arrange for an anya ( nanny, reasonably priced ) if you wish your own time, as a quiet dinner. Remember though that those younger than 4/yrs rarely remember the experience... sure from photos within a year or two after the trip, but by 6-7/yrs, it'll be long forgotten.As you'll have own guide/driver you'll be able to set your own schedule. While there are pools, whether at NBO hotels or when out on safari, few if any are heated, so keep that in mind.

answers.body: Just the usual vomiting and diarrhea. No hospital visits. We all had it at the same time during one night while on safari and staying in a small cabin so likely spoiled food from a roadside stop on the way there. That was a night to remember for sure with only one bathroom between four of us. Several doses of strong antibiotics, water with electrolytes and soda water and 24 hours later all was fine and forgotten.We loved India as my wife has family there. Travelled the southern third and then the golden triangle. India is great for travel with hiring drivers and cars for ten days at a time and with kids it was much cheaper than private safari in Africa. And with the lions and other animals, they will not be off in the distance, they will be right beside the vehicle.

title: 3 Days in Nairobi before Safari - what to do

answers.body: We went on a safari last year. Before the safari we enjoyed 2 days in Nairobi. We hired a driver who picked us up from our hotel (The Sarova Stanley). We went to the Elephant orphanage, Kazuri Bead factory (hand made bead--made by local widows from the area--go and support them if you can--nice jewlery that you can only get in Nairobi) and to the Giraffe Center. We also asked our driver to take us to a shopping center so we could buy some snacks and drinks. He also took us by the slums of Nairobi (Kibera). I wish we would have spent more time in the slums. The people there were so friendly and the living conditions were so much different than what we see in America.We also changed money at a bank at the "mall." This bank had a much better exchange rate than we got at the hotel. Also, it is better to haveKenyashillings for the Elephant orphanage and the Giraffe center. No credit cards accepted and the rate for US money (which they do accept) is far, far worse than if you use their currency.we went to Karen Blixen's Coffee House for lunch too--such a nice place to eat!!! You will love it!Hope this helps!!

body: I am flying into Nairobi on a Saturday evening in August (flight is scheduled to arrive at 6:10pm) in advance of a Kilimanjaro trek the following week - starting from Moshi.Any suggestions on transport?I did look in my Tanzania Lonely Planet book, but am having a lot of trouble sorting through the various options:I think there might be at least one overnight (Scandinavian?) bus leaving late Saturday night. On the other hand, I am considering spending that Saturday night in a Nairobi hotel and then catching a bus on Sunday.Any thoughts/suggestions/recommendations would be greatly appreciated... both about the bus or perhaps about a convenient hotel to stay at for the night in Nairobi if I choose to do that.Thanks!Sam
title: Nairobi to Moshi transport questions

answers.body: I highly discourage overnight buses in East Africa period. It's the height of banditry and when most fatal accidents occur (though this is rare on that route). If you have never been in Africa before (especiallyKenya), it would be nice for you to travel during the day so you have your bearings. People unfamiliar with their surroundings (it seems) are more commonly victims of crime/petty theft. Not to scare you, but I've heard so many stories (and never been a crime victim myself because I'm overly-cautious) so I think you should heed my advise. You would be best-served to take a bus or shuttle the next morning and grab a hotel on Sunday. You will route through Arusha and then onward to Moshi. The Impala shuttle is comfortablehttp://www.impalashuttle.com/and will get you to Moshi. Riverside shuttle is another option, but there have been a few bad reviews on this forum latelyhttp://www.riverside-shuttle.com/.I can't speak for Scandinavian, as the quality of buses change from year to year or month to month. It used to look decent (haven't ever taken them myself) but that can change quickly. I like the shuttles, and they are pretty comfortable compared to the buses. Again a bus in Kenya cannot be compared to a bus in the US.Good luck.
answers.title: 1.Re: Nairobi to Moshi transport questions

answers.body: Best to spend first night in Nairobi, get a good night's rest before considering going onward. Especially not a good idea to do this in the dark.Spend the night in Nairobi and if time allows for when you begin your trek from Moshi, do some sightseeing in/around and maybe head out the followiing day - Monday.However many days in NBO, please no nighttime bus rides. Whether Impala, Riverside or Scandinavia, best to ride during daylight hours.

Then back to the Fairview, so traffic shouldn't be all that much of a factor. And, if the day you are planning this is a Sunday, very little traffic in the morning, though more later in the day.There's also a nice cafe at Utamaduni Crafts (near Kazuri Beads) at more reasonable prices than Karen Blixen Coffee/Tamambo,(but then lots of cuisine choices in NBO, so whatever you might wish). title: Stop-over: Wishing to visit Nairobi National Park

answers.body: For your 4pm departure you have to be back at the airport by 2pm.Keeping that in mind, most sites don't open before 9am... Nairobi Natl Prk,Karen Blixen Museum, Giraffe Center, 11am visit Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage (finished by 12N), time for quick lunch. Each site has a small entry free from a few hundredKenyashillings to, I believe, $40 for theNational Park.Leaving the airport during rush hour it can take you a short 45/min (unlikely) or long 2/hrs to get to your first stop for opening, i.e., Nairobi NP.Deplaning, you have to purchase a Transit Visa $20, suggest you withdraw from ATM some local currency to cover your fees, then go out and find a taxi (negotiate the fare for 4/hrs) for driver to take you to these sites, wait for you and return you to airport by 2pm.I'm sure others will have additional input. Hope this helps

title: 8 hours in Nairobi, please help for the schedule

answers.body: Depends on what your interests are. If you're an Out of Africa fan, you can't miss the Blixen Museum. If you're not an Out of Africa fan, you might not find it so interesting. The museum is very close to theGiraffe Centreand Sheldrick. Don't know if you're interested in any shopping stops but also nearby are Kazuri Beads & Pottery and Utamaduni which has a craft collection (prices a bit high but good quality and selection). If you decide to go to the Blixen Museum in the afternoon, I'd stick with the Carnivore for lunch asHaandiis in Westlands and you don't want to have to drive back and forth across the city. Or pick some place in the Karen/Langata area to have lunch.The Verandahrestaurant at Utamaduni is a nice spot. But of course, not the same atmosphere as Carnivore.I haven't been to theNational Museum. Tried to visit several times but it was always under renovation. Lunch at Haandi would be fine if that's your afternoon plan.Another museum is theRailway Museumby the train station. It houses old engines, rail cars and memorabilia from the East African Railway if that's something that might interest you.Enjoy your trip!

answers.title: 1.Re: Place near Nairobi?

answers.body: In answer to your questions1. Attractions are spread out across Nairobi. For example, places like theGiraffe Centre,Karen Blixen Museum, Elephant Orphanage, Animal Orphanage andNational Parkare all very close to Karen, on the outskirts. If you were to stay somewhere like, say,Macushla House, you would be located in Langata and therefore within 15-20 minutes' driving time of all of the above, traffic permitting. Then, for the downtown attractions such as theNational Museumand others listed in the previous post, you could organise with your hotel / B&B to hire a taxi plus driver for the day to take you into town and wait while you visit them. Alternatively, you could stay in a downtown hotel and do your sightseeing vice versa. Personally speaking, I'd go for the outskirts option as it's cheaper and quieter and Nairobi, IMHO, is a pretty grotty city!2. For accommodation on the outskirts I would recommend:Macushla HouseNgong HouseGiraffe ManorPalacina Suites/ResidenceHTHFL410

answers.body: Assume this is for 2014? What month? How many days in-country?Peak season prices are from July thru October.Know that theGiraffe Manoralready for '14 has limited space and the rate on a full-board basis -BLD- is in the range of $500/pp/nt... checkin 11am, checkout 10am... no hanging around outside these hours unless you are a paying guest.Best you pick-up a guidebook with further details of what's available (game at specific areas), whether you wish to drive or fly between areas. Lots of other useful information.And only way you'll know what your final costs will be... contact a few outfitters (select from the KATO site - www.katokenya.org), sending individual emails to about 6, with your wish list including estimated budget.Bye the way, Nairobi Nat'l Park while interesting is nowhere like a visit to the Masai Mara and/or other parks/reserves. And know that you can see game as close if only sitting in front of your room or tent; you don't always have to go on game drives.During stay in Nairobi, unless selecting a hotel in a questionnable area to beging with, you're safe in most all tourist hotels - much as hotels elsewhere around the world.

answers.title: 3.Re: 1 week to explore area

answers.body: I may be a bit biased, but I feel just remaining in Nairobi doesn't give the best picture ofKenyaas a whole. It is a land of amazing contrasts - from the Coast to the cooler heights. From lush farmland to desert. From well dressed, seemingly rich, people to the desperately poor and needy.You can cross the Equator at over 9000ft and feel cold up there!! You can swim in pools fed by hot springs.........I am a "people person" - most Kenyans are warm hearted and friendly. In your charity work, you are very likely to see needs which may make you a bit uncomfortable doing some touristy things!! If I were you, I'd not make too many plans in advance, unless you want to book a safari. (In that case you can get much advice on this forum.)TIA (This Is Africa) and last minute decisions are the norm, unless it it booking a popular hotel or safari!

answers.body: Hi Mike,I have just returning fromKenyaon a volunteer program based inKibera. Yes i would recommend a trip through Kibera. The only reason i suggest this is because you mentioned your work inUganda. Kibera is not for the average 'tourist'.Things are quite bad there and the mere size of the place is unbelievable. 1.5 million people living in a 'real' slum. It is the largest in all of africa. There is a spot at a school called 'olympic' where you can get a great view of Kibera.Despite the conditions the people, especially the kids, are great.If you can find someone a local that is trustworthy get them to take you through. If you can get them to drive you to an area Jamhuri and then it is a 10min walk to Kibera. If you stay on the outer rim and don't take valuable you will get a better feel than a drive through. Just don't go at night. During the day you shouldn't have any probelms as long as you use common sense. I used to walk to the orphange by myself.Gypsygirl8

answers.body: You can go birding almost anywhere in Nairobi. Karen is a pretty large area, with lots of long, tree-lined roads and lanes, so not realistic to walk around and cover completely. But any large garden or quiet road will have dozens of species. The longstanding regular bird walks in Nairobi are conducted by Fleur Ngweno (immortalised in Nicholas Drayson's novel "A Guide to the Birds of East Africa") which set off from theNational Museumevery Wed morninghttp://naturekenya.org/Happy birding!Richard Trillo

body: HiI will have 2 days in Nairobi mid November, November 14-15 in the weekend before business trip - would like to see wildlife, light hiking ok and no need to do it complete luxury style, but should be safe, hygienic etc - what is recommended to do? I arrive Friday night at 9 pm in Nairobi with KLM.I do not have any budget restrictions as such.Best regardsChristian Wieth
title: Weekend in Nairobi

answers.body: If no budget restrictions, you can consider- first thing Sat morning, transfer to Wilson (domestic) airport for 10am flight to Masai Mara, have game drive, overnight; Sunday morning game drive and afternoon game drive to airstrip for 4pm flight to Wilson.-Instead of the Masai Mara, you could fly 7:30am to Amboseli or (9-something) to Samburu, both known for large elephant herds; Amboseli also has views of Kili; Samburu has species not found elsewhere as: reticulated giraffe, Grevy's zebra, gerenuk, Somali ostrich, Beisa oryx and even wild dogs.However, with these two destinations, there are only morning flights so once back in NBO on Sun, you'd have half-day free, but there is some interesting sightseeing:Karen Blixen Museum, Giraffe Center, by 11am Sheldrick Elephant Orphanage; if you adopt an ellee (see the Sheldrick site) you can arrange to visit your chubby at 5pm to meet the keeper and put your ward to sleep... lots of fun .---You'd incur fee for return flights, 1/nt lodge or camp (many choices at different budgets), meals, park fees, game drives and transfers - your hotel can arrange, but I'd prebook before arrival.Easier and probably less expensive probably- Sat morning, road trip to Lake Nakuru; game drive, hotel overnight Lion Hill Lodge; next morning (Sun) early game drive and drive south (1/hr) to Naivasha for boat ride to Crescent Island for walking safari amongst tame game; return to NBO by evening. (about 2-2.5/hrs drive time)OR- Sat morning, road trip to Ol Pejeta, private conservation - stay at Sweetwater's, Porini Camp or Ol Pejeta Bush Camp (if open in Nov); game drives, night game drives; Sunday, game or walking safaris; return to NBO by evening. (about 2-2.5/hrs drive time).--- Cost for either of these should include: guide/vehicle, park fees, room/tent, meals, game drives and all transfersHope this helps.

body: It looks like we have about a 6 hour layover before coming back home in the Nairobi airport around 5pm. Was thinking about possible going into Nairobi for dinner from the airport. Is this advisable, and if so how is best to do it safely? Thank you.
title: Layover

answers.body: I do this quite often. Land at 4pm from Kigali and then fly out on the 11pm to London. BUT a few provisos: I always check my bags through and I always have my boarding card for the second leg of my flight (online check in is fab), so all I have to do on my return to the airport is go through immigration. I also tend to fly on a Sunday night, when the roads are quiet(er), so I can be in and out of town quickly.You will need to buy a transit visa for $10. If you're not at the front of the queue I wouldn't bother as you'll waste too much time and you might just as well sit at Java Coffee by gate 14.I tend to go to Karen rather than town (nicer restaurants) -Talisman,Rusty Nailetc - just jump in a cab at the airport, and get the restaurant to book one for your return. It'll cost you c1200Ksh into town (30 mins) and c1500Ksh to Karen (40mins). I tend to head back so I'm at the airport 90 mins before the flight.This has gone spectacularly wrong on one occassion when the traffic was so bad it took 4 hours to get back from Karen.If you wanted something closer you could go to dinner at the Parnasi (sp?) Hotel which is about 10 minutess from the airport.If in any doubt on time don't do it.

answers.body: Just be warned about the Nairobi traffic - 5pm could be dreadful!!Our visitors last week took 2 1/2 hours to get into Nairobi at noon and missed their planned trip to the Game Park.Personally I'd not bother!! The Cafe up past Gate 14 looks nice....

title: One night in Nairobi

answers.body: The closest hotels to the airport would be Panari orOle Sereni... about 10-15/min taxi drive, however they're not inexpensive. Going any farther into the city may find yourself in situation next morning with horrific traffic for return to the airport.If leaving the airport to overnight at hotel, you will have to purchase a Visa at USD$50/person and might need for entry toZimbabwea Yellow Fever inoculation and proof of same or you won't be allowed in. I'd check with Zim Embassy if this inoc is needed which is rather expensive. Also, taxi to/from hotel.And, for a 7:20am flight you have to be at airport for check-in/security at minimum 2/hrs prior departure (it's an international flight). Thus, gather you'd have to be up, showered, dressed, had breakfast and out of hotel by 5am.While NBO airport isn't attractive enough nor at all comfortable, services limited... you might do better finding a quiet spot here to catch some Zzzzs. Some shops will be open and though few places to eat, Java (Coffee) House is best you might be able to "hang" here till early morning.Good luck!

answers.body: You don't say whether you are transiting or staying longer? There isn't an airport shuttle bus - some of the better hotels might offer their own transport which you would have to arrange beforehand. The best thing is to order a private cab to wait for you - the driver will meet you at the barriers just outside the customs check at arrivals.As the OPs have mentioned, traffic at that time of the night is negligible, however if you need to return to the airport the next day to catch a flight allow at least 2 hours to get there, especially in the late afternoon or on Fridays. Even if the normal traffic is okay, quite often something happens (like a police shoot out with gangsters, or the presidential calvalcade, or a political speech at the stadium - all of which have happened to me) which stops traffic for hours on end (which means the cab might have trouble even getting to pick you up, let alone deliver you to the airport).If you are staying for a while, choose a hotel near the city or at Westlands - Westlands is safer I reckon, and there are cafes and restaurants there and at the Sarit Centre so you aren't stuck at the hotel, plus shops and the Maasai markets (in tin sheds on the corner opposite Sarit Centre) to buy some gifts. (The touts at the markets can be quite pushy though, so maybe team up with someone else if possible.)Jacaranda Hotelis fine and doesn't charge like a wounded bull.Also check TripAdvisor for guesthouses etc - the Mennonite Guesthouse off Rhapta Road is about 40 mins walk from Westlands shops, for example, but don't walk at night or evening.Andrews Apartments(also a hotel - at the end of Rhapta Road near St Marys schools) is really nice with a quiet green outlook (ask for a room looking over St Marys parkland) and pool, but not sure of their pricing.Also, maybe make a deal with your cab driver to drive you around for your stay - public transport as we know it doesn't exist, and can be dangerous. I can recommend Francis from Westline Travel (+254 (0) 724 988 866), or Nellion cabs (+254 (0) 734 354 738), or JimCabs. One way trip from JKIA into town/Westlands will be 1500 shillings - this is the standard. Further out (say to Karen) would be more.

body: I'm sure there's someone out there who can advise me!I'm staying at theFairview Hotelfor 2 nights in Nairobi before joining a project and would like to do the tourist bit - elephant orphanage etc. for one day. answers.body: Hi skipuss,Using a taxi would be a cheaper option for you but you might need a guide. This is a safe way to travel around Nairobi. Finding an organized group might not be easy because of conflict of dates and timings.Apart from the elephant orphanage you can do the giraffe manor> nice place to interact within the giraffes one on one. The safari walk and animalorphanage also are nice places to visit. All this can be done in one day but the elephant orphanage only opens for one hour. Btw 11 and 12 to minimize their tolerance to human beings.All the best.

answers.body: Or you could adopt a baby ele and then you can arrange to go for longer in the day.
answers.title: 3.Re: Best way to be a single tourist for 1 day in Nairobi

answers.body: A day in Nairobi can be such fun!! Of course, the elephants are a must. Are you a foster parent of one of the orphans? If you are, did you know you can have a more private viewing in the evening when you can meet your baby personally!!! This was definitely a highlight for me. Email the trust to arrange. Other highlights are theGiraffe Centrewhere you can feed the giraffes and learn more about them,Karen Blixen Museum(Out of Africa), Bomas of Africa, a cultural village where you will learn about the tribes and watch them perform,Utamaduni Craft Centrefor more up-market crafts. Carnivore Restaurant is also a lot of fun but probably better if you have company. All of these attractions are in Langata an outer suburb of Nairobi, so all close by to each other.I have friends in the safari business in Nairobi who I would recommend to you, but not sure how their cost would compare to other forms of travel for a single person. Please try them.East Africa Discoveries and Safaris, run by Isaac Kariuki, email safari@eastafricad.co.ke OR eastafricad@yahoo.com.www.eastafricad.co.keAsk for David to guide you ... he is also a friend and a wonderful guide, very professional and polite. I am also a middle aged female and always felt safe in his company. I loveKenyawith a passion and will definitely be going back. I'd love to know more about your project ... please reply??!!!

They're allowed to transfer guests after the park has closed, and transfers and full-on game drives in the park are included in the price. Because it's located on the south side of the national park, you can get from the lodge to anywhere in Karen by popping out through Langata gate and straight to JKIA/Wilson by using East Gate. answers.body: Planning trip to Nairbo,Kenyaend of November. Coming from USA. Is it more economical to pay for food, services, shopping, etc with US dollars or use a VISA card instead exchanging US dollars for shillings?
answers.title: 8.Re: Currency, things to do in five days

answers.body: Food, services (except for hotels/safari) and shopping are priced in Kenya Shillings. Although US Dollars are likely to be accepted, you are unlikely to be offered a favourable exchange rate. It is better to bring some cash which you can exchange, or withdraw Kenya Shillings from ATM's (ensuring that you notify your bank of travel plans). Card payments are accepted in many retail outlets, but more remotely located outlets eg. curio shops will operate on a cash basis.Also, I would urge you to pay tips in Kenya Shillings. Kenyan's are too polite to turn down a tip made in US Dollars. However, the reality is that the member of staff might not be readily able to change the money and will also lose on the exchange, as well as possibly needing to pay for travel to a bank/forex. I also believe that it demonstrates respect and forethought to pay tips in the legal tender.

It was replaced later by theSafari Baron the first floor and later still by theExchange Bar. This last was the birthplace of Nairobi's first and only Stock Exchange where previously four businessmen had sat, since 1954, transacting their business of stocks and shares.

answers.title: 1.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

answers.title: 2.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

answers.body: Not sure if you are doing 1 or 2 visits to the elephant orphanage. Public is 111am-12n and a short talk about the ellies and watching them have their mudbaths. Make sure you either wear something that you don't care about because they can splash the mud on you but fun to watch. The evening visit from 5-6pm, for those that have adopted ellies, is a different experience and very enjoyable. You get to meet the keepers and see your adopted chubby.Kazuri beads is also great. The tour of the bead making area is very interesting and the ladies very proud of their work. Their finished products are very reasonable in cost here. If you buy the same type of items at lodging, they are way more expensive.Utmanduni Crafts is also in the Karen area and is a great place to have lunch and shop. There is no pressure on the shopping like other places you might encounter. You can browse and bring your items to a central checkout. Prices are slightly higher than booths along the road, but it is wonderful to not have to haggle. They have clean bathrooms and their food is good and very reasonable.Laurena
answers.title: 3.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

answers.body: First Free day:A Nairobi Walking Tourwhich includes a walking Safari in Nairobi Central Business District. have a wonderful walk of the city-in-the-sun with a local guide where you have ample time for close photography, bargain and diversified shopping.Visiting the stately Parliament buildings, Kenyatta International Conference Centre and the colorful Nairobi city market lift to the top of KICC to look at Nairobi skyline can be arranged) also are Visits to Kenya National archives & Watatu art gallery.Thereafter, a visit to theSnake ParkandNational Museum: "the Finest Small Museum in Africa" well known for its spell binding exhibits and displays of early man, tribal regalia and the flora and fauna ofKenyaalso a close visit to the botanical garden.Second Free day, I would suggest as it is the last day a Nairobi Cultural Experience Tour with Shopping.If you may have any questions please don't hesitate to contact me.All the best !
answers.title: 4.Re: what to do/see in Nairobi?

Afternoon doKIBERAslum as you go back to Hotel.On 15th Sep, depart Hotel for the OSTRICH FARM at Kitengela 30kms from Nairobi city same route to Airport, spend the whole morning there and after Lunch drive about 15kms from OSTRICH FARM to Airport for your flight, it is will be so nice and good experience.All the best.Ancient Wild.

answers.body: A note on the Nairobi walking tour suggestion:The parliament area is now under hair-trigger security due to terror threats. I would not be walking where you see any obvious security perimeter. I'm not sure where the current perimeter is, but don't stray too near large concentrations of police, and I would not have a camera in my hand either.Anywhere in the Central Business District (CBD), you could attract negative attention these days if you try to capture street views with a camera. A sad state of affairs I realize, but recently a white British terrorist was killed inKenyaand this really got the public's attention.

body: Does anyone have suggestions for a reliable, well priced car-hire company in Nairobi for a short-term rental? A small 4wd (eg Suzuki Jimney) or bakkie or elevated vehicle would be ideal, but small sedan also ok.And any tips on driving, ability to find parking.Thanks
title: Car Hire (self drive) in Nairobi

answers.body: I always recommend Corcorde - I've used them many times and found their Suzukis (well, Marutis) very reliable, and they're well located in the heart of Westlands, just off Waiyaki Way.Driving tips? Where to begin?! You need to be robustly defensive, always alert, and always prepared for the worst possible outcome. It's much better to hire a driver when you hire the vehicle. Parking is a serious problem in the CBD and other busy areas. Buy parking tickets (usually valid all day) from parking wardens. And beware the city askaris, who are a law unto themselves…Happy driving!Richard Trillo

answers.body: Yacht,I supposeBangkokis a fair comparison.If you are only going between Jomo and Karen, with a few trips for birds and NBO Park, I cannot see you encountering any major problems. The Park is off Langata Rd, which is what you will use to get to Keran from Jomo. At the moment there are some works going on there, so it is a little more depressing than usual, but no world shattering.Also, the Park is one of those on the ‘Card system’, you could actually stop and do all the paperwork the day before going in, thus making entry quicker on the morning you visit. Sometimes there can be a queue at the desk, and anything you can do to avoid it gives you more time actually in there! Ideally, you want to hit the Gate at 0630ish.I would also opt for Ngong over Karuru forest, nothing to do with the birds, I don’t know enough, just that the latter is over by Muthaiga and you’d have to battle through town!If you come out early, and are puckish, there is a reasonable place to eat just by the Gift Shop, then you can get back on the road to theGiraffe Centre, that has a small Café too, but is really form emergency eats! You may also wish to consider the Elephant Orphange, also in the area, time dependant.For a good feed in the evening, I would head for theTalisman, excellent place about 2 mins from Karen Shops, get your hotel to book a table though, it can get a little busy and try to eat on the Patio, it makes for a nice evening.Do beware, particularly when heading into the road-works on Langata of Matatus, they don’t take prisoners and will when the traffic merges attempt to push you off the road to make space for themselves. For a first time driver over there, I would say bow out gracefully and let them in, it is better than ending up in the ditch.Be lucky and enjoy!

answers.body: Couple of thoughts:Arriving at JKIA mid-afternoon Friday and trying to drive to Karen, you will probably (depending on flight arrival time) get as far as Uhuru Stadium roundabout before encountering traffic heading left (west) to Karen that will take you 1-2 hours, so don't expect to be in Karen much before dark (6.30pm).I'd suggest you might do better to get a taxis on Friday and Sunday and have a car and driver for the whole of Saturday, someone who will pick you up from where you're staying and drop you back at the end of the day. title: Stuff to do in Nairobi

answers.body: We had a request like that some time back and ended up doing the below itinerary which catered for our day. The trip was made possible by diwaka safaris based in Nairobi and we were provided with an extra free guide..if need be,just write to joseph@diwakasafaris.com11thPicked at 1000hrs for a 20 mins drive to the Daphne Sheldrik Elephant orphanage for a one hour learning experience about the playful young elephants and rhino that were rescued. (1100-1200hrs).The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trustis a small flexible charity, established in memory of David Sheldrick, famous Naturalist and founder Warden of Kenya's giant Tsavo East National Park in which he served from 1948 until 1976.The trust has been active in an educative capacity and provided a blue print for the welfare of animals in captivity and in cases of elephants, illustrated the sophistication of their communication and their social needs.1230hrs: Taken to a restaurant where you pay for your lunch directly1400hrs: Proceed short drive to the nearbyGiraffe Centre.It’s a sanctuary for the rare and beautiful Rothschild Giraffe set by Jock a British-born Kenyan citizen with the help of her American Wife Betty Leslie-Melville. Not only will you get to have a close view of the tall mammals but also be able to have a rare chance to hold a wild animal as you feed them ending with a most wonderful kiss from them. The residents’ warthogs are also a good sight to catch with their “same as” pig behavior.1500hrs: End the day with a visit to theKaren Blixen Museumplus shopping before been dropped back at the Hilton Hotel.A visit to the original home of the famous Danish Authoress of (Out of Africa Movie fame) giving you an incredible chance to learn more about the widely respected woman as you take a graceful walk around the around her spacious bungalow. You can take a walk around the beautiful gardens with spectacular view of the knuckles likeNgong Hillswhere Blixen boyfriend Denys Finch Hatton was remains were laid to rest on May 14 1931.

answers.title: 2.Re: Best use of One Day at Giraffe Manor?

answers.body: Hello,I work withGiraffe Manoras their sales and marketing representative in Europe and hope I can help here. The giraffe visit the Manor in the morning until around 8am. It is difficult to say exactly where they will be and when as they have the whole garden to explore throughout the day, but it is safe to say that you will see them before 8am up at the Manor and also around tea time when they like to come up again! I have arrived at the manor at various times of the day and there is almost always a giraffe in sight , be it by the Manor or just down the hill.Re: what to do, you can walk to the giraffe centre from the Manor so, as you say this is a must. I would suggest going to the private session only at the Daphne Sheldrick orphanage. This is far more personalised and you will be able to ask specific questions about your elephant as well as seeing some of the others. The afternoon session can have as many as 150 people there and, although interesting for those who are not able to have a private viewing, is not as special. I would suggest that, as your time is short that you only do the private session.Depending on what you are most interested in, whilst you are coming back from the Daphne Sheldrick orphanage I would highly recommend stopping in at Marula studios. This is where they recycle flipflops from the Kenyan coast (they are washed up onto the beach and turtles have been killed by trying to eat them so they are removed and brought to Nairobi). Here they are made into all sorts of wonderful things such as toys, jewellery, mats etc. You can look around the factory and then head into the shop to see the end products. Kazuri beads is great for souvenir shopping and Matt Bronze is great to visit / see the bronzes being made and buy something of quality. Karen Blixen is also nice to see if you are interested in her history, but again, depending on your time you may want to get back to the Manor. You really do not want to miss out on the tea on the lawn with giraffe! Once you are back at the Manor you can enjoy the rest of the day / evening there. What is great is that the Manor is close to all these places, so it really comes down to your own preference. Hope this helps and you have a wonderful time there!

answers.body: Here's my 2 shillings worth:Giraffe Manoris a unique place to stay. It's 28km from Nairobi International Airport and assuming you're out of the airport and moving in a vehicle by 7.30am (pretty good going if you are), you won't be at Giraffe Manor until 9 or 9.30am, except possibly on a Sunday. BUT, you won't be able to check-in until 10.45/11am for the reasons Sandi states - there's no waiting area, no lobby and they're checking guests *out* between 10 and 11. So, you'll be hanging around for a bit, possibly at the AFEW Giraffe Centre itself (to which as guests of GM you would have free access, though possibly only once you've checked in…), which is just across the lawn, on the edge of the manor grounds.The bigger question is: if you aren't already holding a room at Giraffe Manor, book one soon. It's often full.As for the question of how to fill the 24 hours: "Karen Blixen museum, bomas, Matt Bronze, Kazuki beads, open air market - which one?" Kazuri Beads is nice, but I wouldn't pass up the opportunity to visitNairobi National Parkproperly - it's a really impressive 60 square miles of wilderness, not some sanitised city park, and you have a very good chance of seeing lions, and even greater chance (amazingly) of seeing both black and white rhinos.Have a great stay in Nairobi - a greatly underrated city.Richard Trillo

body: I got roped into a holiday with the family toKenyaand am a bit nervous as my 2.5 year old toddler with be accompanying us too! Any comments on how child-friendly a place Nairobi is? My main queries surround entertainment (parks/playgrounds), health and safety (food/water) and infrastructure (cleanliness, public toilets, change-facilities, etc). Its too late to change plans now, so the best I can do is make sure that my kid is healthy, relatively well entertained and happy! We're going on a couple of private safaris where kids are allowed, though I wonder if he'll really enjoy them. Any warnings, pointers, hints, suggestions, advice is welcome!
title: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: I'm not sure I would have taken such a young child. I think 5 is possibly the earliest I would take a little one. At the very least they need to be able to take malaria prophylactics and I don't think I could have got the tablets into my kids at that age.Having said that just make sure that he/she has all the recommended jabs; use bottled water; take care with the sun - all the things that apply to anyone really - and you should be OK.There are things for little ones in Nairobi - the elephant orphanage and giraffe centre are perfect. There is also Uhuru park which has pedallos, rides etc. Most hotels have swimming pools too so you should be able to fill the time that you are there and most Kenyans do like children - well at least that's been my experience.
answers.title: 1.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: We took our two young ones last year ages 4 and 8 (younger one turned 5 while in the Mara - "best birthday present ever") We had private driver so that we could change plans, stop whenever needed, etc. Children will love it, but maybe not remember it as much as an older child would.We were able to get medicine in them by crushing and mixing with chocolate pudding so it can be done. Bottle water all the way, hats, sunscreen and short days and you will be fine. If you have not already, be sure to visit travel clinic and get antibiotic prescriptions filled ahead for all travellers and take with you for emergency. We were there for 35 days and used ours.Don't expect to be taking a stroller as it will be useless on the poor roads, sidewalks except maybe in downtown Nairobi. Back pack carrier for that age might be useful. But taxis and guide will get you wherever you need to go so you should not have to carry that much.And to compare, we also went to India for 60 days when youngest was at the around same age as yours.Kenyais much cleaner and safer than crowed India.
answers.title: 2.Re: Nairobi and Kenya for toddlers

answers.body: Be sure to prearrange for a bed (even a crib) with a bed net for the little one. Not all camps/lodges have these as they're not always necessary, but I sure would for a little one. And for certain be sure to give him/her their malaria meds daily. There are a few types, but Malarone does have a pediatric dosage for child under 40lbs. Discuss with doc meds and inocs that all might need as even most adults haven't been since childhood - Tetanus, HepA, Polio.Besides forgetting about a stroller, know that most safari vehicles have seat belts but NOT childseats, so you might want to seriously consider one as the roads in some areas aren't the best. The little one will also often need a nap midday, so having one is best.Also be aware that you can arrange for an anya ( nanny, reasonably priced ) if you wish your own time, as a quiet dinner. Remember though that those younger than 4/yrs rarely remember the experience... sure from photos within a year or two after the trip, but by 6-7/yrs, it'll be long forgotten.As you'll have own guide/driver you'll be able to set your own schedule. While there are pools, whether at NBO hotels or when out on safari, few if any are heated, so keep that in mind.

answers.body: Just the usual vomiting and diarrhea. No hospital visits. We all had it at the same time during one night while on safari and staying in a small cabin so likely spoiled food from a roadside stop on the way there. That was a night to remember for sure with only one bathroom between four of us. Several doses of strong antibiotics, water with electrolytes and soda water and 24 hours later all was fine and forgotten.We loved India as my wife has family there. Travelled the southern third and then the golden triangle. India is great for travel with hiring drivers and cars for ten days at a time and with kids it was much cheaper than private safari in Africa. And with the lions and other animals, they will not be off in the distance, they will be right beside the vehicle.
